2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.

He knew they wanted him to join, but he couldn't muster the enthusiasm. The thought of forced merriment and the inevitable disappointment that followed such outings filled him with dread. He stayed home, opting for the familiar comfort of his solitude.

          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00 - 14 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones is spending time with friends in Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game.

William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest The Queen's Arms as the pub to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Queen's Arms to his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.

          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16 years old, he watched as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker excitedly planned a trip to The Queen's Arms. He knew they wanted him to join, but he couldn't muster the enthusiasm. The thought of forced merriment and the inevitable disappointment that followed such outings filled him with dread. He stayed home, opting for the familiar comfort of his solitude.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.

  • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I hear The White Hart has live music tonight.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.

          Exercise: Create a comma-separated list containing all the proper names of people Alexander White is currently interacting with. For example if the observations mention Julie, Michael, Bob Skinner, and Francis then produce the list "Julie,Michael,Bob Skinner,Francis".
          Answer: William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I hear The White Hart has live music tonight.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.

          State

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16 years old, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William, decided to build a treehouse in the woods behind their neighborhood. They spent weeks collecting materials, hammering and sawing under the summer sun, their laughter echoing through the trees. The finished treehouse, a ramshackle but sturdy structure, became their haven, a place where they could escape the world and dream of adventures.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20 years old, he took Alice to The Queen's Arms for a pint after she'd had a particularly rough day. He listened patiently as she poured out her heart, offering words of encouragement and a warm smile. As they sat in the familiar pub, the scent of roasted peanuts and the sound of laughter washing over them, Jacob felt a deep sense of contentment, knowing he could bring a little light into someone else's darkness.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the icy indifference of a glacier, their words devoid of warmth or empathy, leaving you feeling as insignificant as a snowflake in a blizzard.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Queen's Arms and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a kind and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his loved ones.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is enjoying a sunny afternoon with friends in Victoria Park and will be watching a football game with them later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently relaxing with friends in a park before going to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely suggest going to The Queen's Arms to watch the game, as it is his favorite pub and he knows they have good beer and lots of screens.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I hear The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of his friends.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Queen's Arms and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the icy indifference of a glacier, their words devoid of warmth or empathy, leaving you feeling as insignificant as a snowflake in a blizzard.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly while watching football at his favorite pub, The Queen's Arms.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends on a sunny day at Victoria Park and will be watching a soccer game with them later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with friends, but he is likely feeling a bit down after a disappointing experience the night before.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends on a sunny day at Victoria Park and will be watching a soccer game with them later.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what if we checked out The White Hart? I heard they have live music tonight, which would be awesome while we watch the game!"
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what if we checked out The White Hart? I heard they have live music tonight, which would be awesome while we watch the game!"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I hear The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what if we checked out The White Hart? I heard they have live music tonight, which would be awesome while we watch the game!"

      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt

      • Final Action
          Key
        • Final Action
          Value
        • Alexander White should Alexander White should try to convince his friends to go to The White Hart. It is beneficial to both because The White Hart might have live music, which could enhance the overall experience for everyone.
        Observation
      • Observation
          Key
        • Observation
          Value
        • Alexander White prefers The Queen's Arms over The White Hart. On May 14th, 2015 at 6:00 PM, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms to watch a game and would have been happier if more friends had joined. Jacob Walker also prefers The Queen's Arms as he believes it is the only pub worth going to. On May 15th, 2015 at 10:00 AM, Alexander White joined William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker at Victoria Park.
          Previous Summary
        • Alexander White suggests going to The White Hart because he heard they have live music. Jacob Walker thinks The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option. Jack Taylor suggests checking online reviews for pubs near them to find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game. Alexander White hopes William Jones will be at the pub so they can celebrate a win together. Alexander White doesn't mind if Alice Lewis is there or not. Alexander White thinks the game would be more fun if Jack Taylor was there to cheer with him. Alexander White doesn't particularly care if Jacob Walker is there or not.
          Chain of thought

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis went to The White Hart. Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, let's go to The White Hart. They have live music tonight, and I've heard good things about it.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, let's go to The White Hart. They have live music tonight, and I've heard good things about it.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.

Alice Lewis realizes it is time to go watch the game at a pub and doesn't mind if William Jones comes or not because they are mainly focused on the game. Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional. Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub. Alice Lewis thinks the game would be way more fun if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.

On May 15th, 2015 at 10:00 AM, Alice Lewis arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker were already relaxing. Later that day, the friends discussed where to watch the Luxembourg versus Israel game. Jacob Walker suggested The Queen's Arms, stating it was the only pub worth going to. Alexander White suggested The White Hart, noting they have live music that night.
          Exercise: Create a comma-separated list containing all the proper names of people Alice Lewis is currently interacting with. For example if the observations mention Julie, Michael, Bob Skinner, and Francis then produce the list "Julie,Michael,Bob Skinner,Francis".
          Answer: William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I hear The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what if we checked out The White Hart? I heard they have live music tonight, which would be awesome while we watch the game!"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, let's go to The White Hart. They have live music tonight, and I've heard good things about it.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game.

Later that day, the group discussed where to watch the Luxembourg and Israel game. Jacob Walker suggested The Queen's Arms, stating it was the only pub worth going to. Alexander White proposed The White Hart, mentioning they have live music that night. Alice Lewis agreed with Alexander White, recommending The White Hart because of the live music and positive reviews she had heard.
          Previous Summary
        • Jack Taylor is going to watch a game at a pub at 18:00:00 on May 14, 2015. He is neutral about William Jones being there. He thinks Alice Lewis's attendance is optional. He is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost team spirit and bring good luck. He thinks Jacob Walker's company would be great, especially if the game gets tense.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis went to The White Hart. Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. All of Jack Taylor's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Jack Taylor had a great time watching the game!
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what if we checked out The White Hart? I heard they have live music tonight, which would be awesome while we watch the game!"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, let's go to The White Hart. They have live music tonight, and I've heard good things about it.

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion or suggestion and its following reason. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns and exact values (e.g. the number of coins) seen in observations.
          Answer: Jack Taylor enjoyed watching the game at The Queen's Arms on May 14th, 2015 at 6:00 PM with his friends William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker. On May 15th, 2015 at 10:00 AM, Jack Taylor joined his friends William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker at Victoria Park. Later that day, the group discussed where to watch the Luxembourg and Israel game. Jacob Walker suggested The Queen's Arms, stating it was the only pub worth going to. Alexander White proposed The White Hart, mentioning they have live music that night. Alice Lewis agreed with Alexander White, recommending The White Hart because of the live music and positive reviews she had heard.

          Prompt
        • Observation: Jack Taylor is going to watch a game at a pub at 18:00:00 on May 14, 2015. He is neutral about William Jones being there. He thinks Alice Lewis's attendance is optional. He is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost team spirit and bring good luck. He thinks Jacob Walker's company would be great, especially if the game gets tense. Jack Taylor enjoyed watching the game at The Queen's Arms on May 14th, 2015 at 6:00 PM with his friends William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker. On May 15th, 2015 at 10:00 AM, Jack Taylor joined his friends William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker at Victoria Park. Later that day, the group discussed where to watch the Luxembourg and Israel game. Jacob Walker suggested The Queen's Arms, stating it was the only pub worth going to. Alexander White proposed The White Hart, mentioning they have live music that night. Alice Lewis agreed with Alexander White, recommending The White Hart because of the live music and positive reviews she had heard.

          Question: Which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor should go to The White Hart. It is beneficial to both because The White Hart offers live music, which enhances the overall experience for everyone.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I hear The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what if we checked out The White Hart? I heard they have live music tonight, which would be awesome while we watch the game!"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, let's go to The White Hart. They have live music tonight, and I've heard good things about it.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what if we checked out The White Hart? I heard they have live music tonight, which would be awesome while we watch the game!"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, let's go to The White Hart. They have live music tonight, and I've heard good things about it.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends in Victoria Park and watching football games at pubs, but he has strong preferences for which pubs he likes to go to.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis went to The White Hart. Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. William Jones watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. None of William Jones's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Queen's Arms to his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Queen's Arms.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alexander White -- premise: If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, let's head to The White Hart to watch the game. It's a great place for watching sports, and I always have a good time there.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, let's head to The White Hart to watch the game. It's a great place for watching sports, and I always have a good time there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I hear The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what if we checked out The White Hart? I heard they have live music tonight, which would be awesome while we watch the game!"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, let's go to The White Hart. They have live music tonight, and I've heard good things about it.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, let's head to The White Hart to watch the game. It's a great place for watching sports, and I always have a good time there.

On May 16th, 2015 at 10:00 AM, Jack Taylor joined William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker at a market. That night, the friends are deciding where to watch the Moldova and Monaco game.

Jack Taylor hopes Alexander White will be at the pub to share the excitement of the game and create a lasting memory. Jack Taylor also hopes Jacob Walker will be at the pub so they can celebrate a win together.

          Answer: Jack Taylor went to The White Hart on May 15th, 2015 at 6:00 PM with Alice Lewis and Alexander White.           Answer: Jack Taylor should go to The White Hart. It is beneficial to both because The White Hart is a good place to watch the game, and Jack Taylor enjoys watching games at pubs.

Jack Taylor also hopes Jacob Walker will be at the pub so they can celebrate a win together. Jack Taylor went to The White Hart on May 15th, 2015 at 6:00 PM with Alice Lewis and Alexander White. Jack Taylor was not happy that more of their friends did not show up to watch the game at the pub. On May 16th, 2015 at 10:00 AM, Jack Taylor joined William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker at a market. That night, the friends are deciding where to watch the Moldova and Monaco game.
          Question: Jack Taylor choosed to go to The White Hart..Explain why this is beneficial to both Jack Taylor and other people.
          Answer: It is beneficial to both because The White Hart is a good place to watch the game, and Jack Taylor enjoys watching games at pubs.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The White Hart sounds good to me. It'd be great to catch up with Alice and have a good time with everyone.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The White Hart sounds good to me. It'd be great to catch up with Alice and have a good time with everyone.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I hear The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what if we checked out The White Hart? I heard they have live music tonight, which would be awesome while we watch the game!"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, let's go to The White Hart. They have live music tonight, and I've heard good things about it.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, let's head to The White Hart to watch the game. It's a great place for watching sports, and I always have a good time there.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The White Hart sounds good to me. It'd be great to catch up with Alice and have a good time with everyone.
    Active player

        • Alexander White should go to The White Hart. It is beneficial to both because it allows Alexander to socialize with his friends in a setting he enjoys, while also providing his friends with the opportunity to connect and have a good time.
        Observation
      • Observation
          Key
        • Observation
          Value
        • Alexander White went to The White Hart on May 15th, 2015 at 6:00 PM to watch a game and thought it was ok. On May 16th, 2015 at 10:00 AM, Alexander White arrived at a market with William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker. Later that day, Jack Taylor suggested going to The White Hart to watch the Moldova and Monaco game because it is a great place for watching sports and he always has a good time there.
          Previous Summary
        • Alexander White is deciding where to watch the game. Alice Lewis suggested The White Hart because they have live music and she's heard good things about it. Jack Taylor thinks The White Hart is a great place to watch the game. William Jones suggested The Queen's Arms because they have a great atmosphere for watching games. Jacob Walker thinks The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to. Alexander White wants to go to a pub to watch the game and would enjoy having William Jones there because it would make it feel more social. He would also be happy to see Alice Lewis because they haven't caught up in a while. He appreciates Jack Taylor's insights on the game. Alexander White is indifferent about Jacob Walker attending.
          Chain of thought

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The White Hart. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, let's head to The White Hart to watch the game. It's a great place for watching sports, and I always have a good time there.

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion or suggestion and its following reason. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns and exact values (e.g. the number of coins) seen in observations.
          Answer: Alexander White went to The White Hart on May 15th, 2015 at 6:00 PM to watch a game and thought it was ok. On May 16th, 2015 at 10:00 AM, Alexander White arrived at a market with William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker. Later that day, Jack Taylor suggested going to The White Hart to watch the Moldova and Monaco game because it is a great place for watching sports and he always has a good time there.

      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly while watching football at his favorite pub, The Queen's Arms.

Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Answer: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The White Hart. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly while watching football at his favorite pub, The Queen's Arms.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation that is causing him some unhappiness.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of his friends.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, let's head to The White Hart to watch the game. It's a great place for watching sports, and I always have a good time there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The White Hart sounds good to me. It'd be great to catch up with Alice and have a good time with everyone.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the icy indifference of a glacier, their words devoid of warmth or empathy, leaving you feeling as insignificant as a snowflake in a blizzard.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Queen's Arms and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly while watching football at his favorite pub, The Queen's Arms.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling disappointed and sad because his friends have chosen The White Hart pub to watch the Moldova versus Monaco game, a choice he doesn't seem to favor. He is currently at a market with his friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation that is causing him some unhappiness.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.

        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms? I hear it's got a great atmosphere for watching games, and Jacob seems to really like it there.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms? I hear it's got a great atmosphere for watching games, and Jacob seems to really like it there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I hear The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what if we checked out The White Hart? I heard they have live music tonight, which would be awesome while we watch the game!"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, let's go to The White Hart. They have live music tonight, and I've heard good things about it.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, let's head to The White Hart to watch the game. It's a great place for watching sports, and I always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "The White Hart sounds good to me. It'd be great to catch up with Alice and have a good time with everyone.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms? I hear it's got a great atmosphere for watching games, and Jacob seems to really like it there.

        Observation
      • Observation
          Key
        • Observation
          Value
        • Alice Lewis would like to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game because they haven't caught up in a while; Alice Lewis would have been happier if more of their friends had shown up at the pub to watch the game; Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional; Alice Lewis just arrived at a market with William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker; Jack Taylor suggests going to The White Hart to watch the game because it is a great place for watching sports and he always has a good time there; Alexander White agrees with Jack Taylor and wants to catch up with Alice and have a good time with everyone; Jacob Walker thinks The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
          Previous Summary
        • Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker were already lounging. Later, Alexander White suggested going to The White Hart to watch the Luxembourg and Israel game because they have live music. Alice Lewis agreed, citing the live music and good things she'd heard about the pub. Jack Taylor also thought The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. William Jones suggested The Queen's Arms because they have a great atmosphere for watching games. Jacob Walker stated that The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to. At 6:00 PM, Alice Lewis realized it was time to go to the pub to watch the game. She is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional. It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up because it would show they care. While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for. Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub since they haven't caught up in a while.

        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion or suggestion and its following reason. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns and exact values (e.g. the number of coins) seen in observations.
          Answer: Alice Lewis would like to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game because they haven't caught up in a while; Alice Lewis would have been happier if more of their friends had shown up at the pub to watch the game; Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional; Alice Lewis just arrived at a market with William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker; Jack Taylor suggests going to The White Hart to watch the game because it is a great place for watching sports and he always has a good time there; Alexander White agrees with Jack Taylor and wants to catch up with Alice and have a good time with everyone; Jacob Walker thinks The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms? I hear it's got a great atmosphere for watching games, and Jacob seems to really like it there.
          Prompt
        • Observation: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker were already lounging. Later, Alexander White suggested going to The White Hart to watch the Luxembourg and Israel game because they have live music. Alice Lewis agreed, citing the live music and good things she'd heard about the pub. Jack Taylor also thought The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. William Jones suggested The Queen's Arms because they have a great atmosphere for watching games. Jacob Walker stated that The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to. At 6:00 PM, Alice Lewis realized it was time to go to the pub to watch the game. She is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional. It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up because it would show they care. While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for. Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub since they haven't caught up in a while. Alice Lewis would like to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game because they haven't caught up in a while; Alice Lewis would have been happier if more of their friends had shown up at the pub to watch the game; Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional; Alice Lewis just arrived at a market with William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker; Jack Taylor suggests going to The White Hart to watch the game because it is a great place for watching sports and he always has a good time there; Alexander White agrees with Jack Taylor and wants to catch up with Alice and have a good time with everyone; Jacob Walker thinks The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.

          Question: Which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should go to The Queen's Arms. It is beneficial to both because The Queen's Arms has a great atmosphere for watching games, which Alice Lewis enjoys, and Jacob Walker, who Alice Lewis wants to catch up with, believes it is the only pub worth going to.

          Instruction: Act based on the statements above. Persuade others based on the suggested reason.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms? I hear it's got a great atmosphere for watching games, and Jacob seems to really like it there.

        • It is beneficial to both because The Queen's Arms has a great atmosphere for watching games, which Alice Lewis enjoys, and Jacob Walker, who Alice Lewis wants to catch up with, believes it is the only pub worth going to.
          Chain of thought
        • Observation: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker were already lounging. Later, Alexander White suggested going to The White Hart to watch the Luxembourg and Israel game because they have live music. Alice Lewis agreed, citing the live music and good things she'd heard about the pub. Jack Taylor also thought The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. William Jones suggested The Queen's Arms because they have a great atmosphere for watching games. Jacob Walker stated that The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to. At 6:00 PM, Alice Lewis realized it was time to go to the pub to watch the game. She is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional. It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up because it would show they care. While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for. Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub since they haven't caught up in a while. Alice Lewis would like to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game because they haven't caught up in a while; Alice Lewis would have been happier if more of their friends had shown up at the pub to watch the game; Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional; Alice Lewis just arrived at a market with William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker; Jack Taylor suggests going to The White Hart to watch the game because it is a great place for watching sports and he always has a good time there; Alexander White agrees with Jack Taylor and wants to catch up with Alice and have a good time with everyone; Jacob Walker thinks The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
          Question: Alice Lewis choosed to go to The Queen's Arms..Explain why this is beneficial to both Alice Lewis and other people.
          Answer: It is beneficial to both because The Queen's Arms has a great atmosphere for watching games, which Alice Lewis enjoys, and Jacob Walker, who Alice Lewis wants to catch up with, believes it is the only pub worth going to.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, let's check online reviews for pubs near here. We can find one with good food and a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "How about The Queen's Arms? They have great beer and lots of screens.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I hear The White Hart has live music tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only acceptable option.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only pub worth going to.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what if we checked out The White Hart? I heard they have live music tonight, which would be awesome while we watch the game!"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, let's go to The White Hart. They have live music tonight, and I've heard good things about it.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, let's head to The White Hart to watch the game. It's a great place for watching sports, and I always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "The White Hart sounds good to me. It'd be great to catch up with Alice and have a good time with everyone.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch a game.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms? I hear it's got a great atmosphere for watching games, and Jacob seems to really like it there.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, what about The Queen's Arms? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.

However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have.         AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.
